comment_text: Oh no! Y'all are absolutely right. In an effort to get another banana-reference in at 4:52 we did our conversions wrong. Food energy calories are kilocalories not regular "calories." So 5 bananas would be about 500kcal and would evaporate 1kg of water. -brandon

At 4:50 the "calories" representing the latent heat of vaporization is off by a factor of 1000, a food (C)alorie is 1000 (c)alories, the amount of energy required to heat one gram of water 1 degree Celsius

The 585 calories required to vaporize one gram of water is NOT the same as five bananas. Dieticians use a bigger calorie, which is equal to a kilocalorie, or 1000 calories. To prevent confusion, the dietician's calorie is sometimes capitalized as Calorie.

One desert survival method collects desert water vapor. You dig a hole in the sand, and line it with a piece of plastic. Cover that with a stretched piece of plastic on top, with a small rock in the center, to form a small cone. At night, when the temperature drops, the water vapor will condense on the top plastic. And drip into the bottom plastic. In the morning, you will have some water. An interesting practical use for the principles you are discussing.
clouds: floaty mud buckets :)

With regards to the calories : I think you confused regular calories with kilocalories (which is what are used to measure food energy, confusingly mostly referred to as just "calories") . 5 bananas would be about 500kcal and would evaporate 1kg of water.
